best.why: It keeps the manifesto's clipped, declarative cadence and lands directly on the core thesis: judgment as authorship. No extra lore, no dated references, no tonal detours. It reads like the next paragraph of Section I, not a separate poem.

worst.why: It shifts into bodily and quasi-religious theater (vomit, holy, licking the floor) that feels out of register with the manifesto's clean, analytical force. The rhetoric becomes the point instead of the claim.

must_survive_line: A Slopist does not sign a prompt. A Slopist signs the cut: what was refused, what was spared, what was framed, what was named.
